Hi Martin,

I also find this kind of research very interesting. After readi=
ng numerous
papers like this (including the one you point out) about the va=
rious
properties of natural neurons and synapses and how they affect the
or=
ganisation and behaviour of the network (eg how neurons and connections
are=
 created, how connections change in efficacy, how connections decide
where =
to connect, etc), I get the feeling that these properties are far
more impo=
rtant (in natural neural networks) than a precise (initial)
connection map =
(i.e. where a genome encodes the topology and connection
strengths, either =
directly (NEAT) or indirectly (HyperNEAT)). What seems
more important is th=
e interplay of these properties of different types of
neurons and synapses =
that allows the network to self-organise in such a way
that it performs the=
 required functions. The self-organisation creates the
detailed form and fu=
nction of the brain (eg topology and connection
strengths). It seems more l=
ike natural genomes encode the neuron and
synapse types, and which regions =
of the brain they go in, and the
properties of these neuron and synapse typ=
es. I suspect there are still
some regions where the genome encodes, one wa=
y or another, a fairly precise
topology (though even in this case the genom=
e could make use of how the
neurons and synapses self-organise).

There's s=
ome work on evolving networks that perform "online adaptation" in
control t=
asks (eg controlling a differential-drive robot in a navigation
task), wher=
e the initial connection weights are randomised and the genome
only encodes=
 the synaptic plasticity parameters, e.g. see "Evolution of
Plastic Neuroco=
ntrollers for Situated Agents" and later work by Dario
Floreano. The self-o=
rganisation dynamics of the synaptic plasticity rules
(and the inputs from =
the environment) determine the weights of the
connections.

As part of my c=
urrent work I'm planning on reproducing many of these
properties, including=
 synaptic transmission delays, in a neural network
model to see how they af=
fect the evolvability and capabilities of evolved
networks performing onlin=
e learning. I'm planning on using HyperNEAT or a
variant like ES-HyperNEAT,=
 and am in the middle of implementing these kinds
of properties in a neural=
 network model and creating a flexible HyperNEAT
set-up to allow specifying=
 the parameters for models of these properties.
The motivation being that a=
 lot of these properties have been implicated in
learning processes in the =
brain. See http://ojcoleman.com/node/1 and
http://ojcoleman.com/node/3 for =
details and links to the software. ;)

Cheers,
Oliver


T: 0421 972 953 | E=
: oliver.coleman@... | W: http://ojcoleman.com



On 14 March 2013 03=
:09, martin_pyka <martin.pyka@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Hi everybody,
>=

> I recently stumbled upon a paper that I found very inspiring and somehow=

> changed my perspective on neural networks.
>
> Polychronization: Computa=
tion with spikes
> http://www.izhikevich.org/publications/spnet.htm
> (for =
a rough but fast impression of the idea I recommend fig. 2 and fig. 6)
>
> =
Besides the particular concept of polychronous groups analyzed in this
> st=
udy, the paper highlights the fact that neurons in natural neural
> network=
s have connections with heterogenous conduction delays (with
> submilliseco=
nd precision) and that this heterogeneity contributes to the
> function of =
the network.
>
> As with increasing distance of two neurons the conduction =
delay between
> both neurons increases as well which in turn affects the fu=
nction of the
> neurons, I am wondering whether heterogenous conduction del=
ays represent an
> important additional link to relate the form of a networ=
k to its function.
> I know, this is true for something like sound localiza=
tion (
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coincidence_detection_in_neurobiology=
#Sound_localization)
> but maybe heterogenous conduction delays are also im=
portant in the
> implementation of other functions.
>
> Of course, I immedi=
ately thought about implementing it in HyperNEAT but
> haven't done it yet =
;)
>
> Just in case someone of you finds time to read this paper I would be=

> interested in hearing your thoughts about the ideas in it and whether yo=
u
> think they can be combined with methods in the field of Artificial
> De=
velopment.
>
> Best,
> Martin
>
>  
>

--089e013d1722a1981604d7d768a1

viour of the network (eg how neurons and connections are created, how conne=

eural networks) than a precise (initial) connection map (i.e.=A0where a gen=
ome encodes the topology and connection strengths, either directly (NEAT) o=
r indirectly (HyperNEAT)).=A0What seems more important=A0is the interplay o=
f these properties of different types of neurons and synapses that allows t=
he network to self-organise in such a way that it performs the required fun=

 a fairly precise topology (though even in this case the genome could make =
use of how the neurons and synapses self-organise).</div>

l.com" target=3D"_blank">martin.pyka@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><bl=

<u></u>










<div style>
<span>=A0</sp=
an>


<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>Hi everybody,<br>
<b=
r>
I recently stumbled upon a paper that I found very inspiring and somehow=
 changed my perspective on neural networks. <br>
<br>
Polychronization: Com=
putation with spikes<br>
<a href=3D"http://www.izhikevich.org/publications/=
spnet.htm" target=3D"_blank">http://www.izhikevich.org/publications/spnet.h=
tm</a><br>
(for a rough but fast impression of the idea I recommend fig. 2 =
and fig. 6)<br>
<br>
Besides the particular concept of polychronous groups =
analyzed in this study, the paper highlights the fact that neurons in natur=
al neural networks have connections with heterogenous conduction delays (wi=
th submillisecond precision) and that this heterogeneity contributes to the=
 function of the network. <br>

<br>
As with increasing distance of two neu=
rons the conduction delay between both neurons increases as well which in t=
urn affects the function of the neurons, I am wondering whether heterogenou=
s conduction delays represent an important additional link to relate the fo=
rm of a network to its function. I know, this is true for something like so=
und localization (<a href=3D"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coincidence_detec=
tion_in_neurobiology#Sound_localization" target=3D"_blank">http://en.wikipe=
dia.org/wiki/Coincidence_detection_in_neurobiology#Sound_localization</a>) =
but maybe heterogenous conduction delays are also important in the implemen=
tation of other functions.<br>

<br>
Of course, I immediately thought about=
 implementing it in HyperNEAT but haven't done it yet ;)<br>
<br>
Just =
in case someone of you finds time to read this paper I would be interested =
in hearing your thoughts about the ideas in it and whether you think they c=
an be combined with methods in the field of Artificial Development.<br>

<b=
r>
Best,<br>
Martin<br>
<br>
</p>

    </div>

"color:#fff;min-height:0"></div>


</div>
